title: Aircraft propulsion assembly

events.title: Application filed by Bell Helicopter Textron Inc
Assigned to BELL HELICOPTER TEXTRON INC.
description: ASSIGNMENT OF ASSIGNORS INTEREST (SEE DOCUMENT FOR DETAILS).
Assignors: OLDROYD, PAUL K., McCULLOUGH, John Richard

classifications.description: Aircraft capable of landing or taking-off vertically, e.g. vertical take-off and landing [VTOL] aircraft having its flight directional axis horizontal when grounded the lift during taking-off being created by free or ducted propellers or by blowers the propellers being tiltable relative to the fuselage
Blades foldable to facilitate stowage of aircraft
Aircraft capable of landing or taking-off vertically, e.g. vertical take-off and landing [VTOL] aircraft having its flight directional axis vertical when grounded
Aircraft not otherwise provided for characterised by special use
Aircraft not otherwise provided for having disc- or ring-shaped wings
Dropping, ejecting, or releasing articles the articles being load-carrying devices
Transmitting power from power plants to propellers or rotors; Arrangements of transmissions
Arrangement thereof in or on aircraft
Modular constructions of airplanes or helicopters

abstract: In some embodiments, a propulsion assembly for an aircraft includes a nacelle, at least one self-contained fuel tank disposed within the nacelle operable to contain a liquid fuel, an engine disposed within the nacelle operable to run on the liquid fuel, a drive system mechanically coupled to the engine and operable to rotate responsive to rotation of the engine, a rotor hub mechanically coupled to the drive system operable to rotate responsive to rotation of the drive system and a proprotor mechanically coupled to the rotor hub and operable to rotate therewith.
claims: 2. The propulsion assembly as recited in claim 1 wherein the engine further comprises a rotary engine.
3. The propulsion assembly as recited in claim 1 wherein the drive system provides a reduction between revolutions of the engine and revolutions of the rotor hub.
4. The propulsion assembly as recited in claim 1 wherein the proprotor further comprises a plurality of proprotor blades.
5. The propulsion assembly as recited in claim 1 wherein the proprotor further comprises a plurality of folding proprotor blades.
6. The propulsion assembly as recited in claim 1 wherein the thrust vector has a maximum pitch angle of about twenty degrees.
7. The propulsion assembly as recited in claim 1 further comprising an electronics node operable to control operations of the propulsion assembly.
8. The propulsion assembly as recited in claim 7 wherein the electronics node further comprises controllers operable to send commands to the engine.

9. The propulsion assembly as recited in claim 7 wherein the electronics node further comprises sensors operable to monitor parameters associated with the at least one self-contained fuel tank, the engine and the drive system.
11. The aircraft as recited in claim 10 wherein the thrust vector has a maximum pitch angle of about twenty degrees.

12. The aircraft as recited in claim 10 wherein each of the propulsion assemblies further comprises an electronics node including controllers operable to send commands to the engine and sensors operable to monitor parameters associated with the at least one self-contained fuel tank, the engine and the drive system.
13. The aircraft as recited in claim 10 wherein, for each propulsion assembly, the engine further comprises a rotary engine.
14. The aircraft as recited in claim 10 wherein, for each propulsion assembly, the drive system provides a reduction between revolutions of the engine and revolutions of the rotor hub.
15. The aircraft as recited in claim 10 wherein, for each propulsion assembly, the proprotor further comprises a plurality of proprotor blades.
16. The aircraft as recited in claim 10 wherein, for each propulsion assembly, the proprotor further comprises a plurality of folding proprotor blades.
